message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Since the patient has confirmed Bordetella pertussis infection, prophylaxis is required for close contacts. Azithromycin is recommended for prophylaxis in children under 6 months of age who are at high risk of severe disease, such as the patient's 3-month-old brother. Clarithromycin or azithromycin can be used for prophylaxis in close contacts older than 6 months. The patient will not have lifelong immunity against Bordetella pertussis and her classmates should receive a TdaP booster only if they are not up to date with their vaccination status.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Azithromycin is the recommended prophylactic treatment for close contacts of a patient with confirmed pertussis who are younger than 1 year old or who have certain medical conditions. This includes the patient's younger brother who is 3-months-old. Clarithromycin is not recommended for prophylaxis. While the patient will develop immunity to pertussis, it is not lifelong and booster vaccinations are necessary. However, the recommendation for classmates of the patient is to receive a Tdap booster if they have not been vaccinated in the past 10 years, not regardless of their vaccination status.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Option A is correct because infants under 12 months of age are at risk of severe complications from pertussis, and therefore household members and close contacts should receive prophylactic antibiotics. Option B is incorrect as prophylaxis is only indicated for close contacts of the affected patient, not the entire class. Option C is incorrect as natural immunity wanes over time and a booster vaccine is recommended for adults and adolescents. Option D is also incorrect as classmates only need a Tdap booster if they have not been fully vaccinated with the pertussis vaccine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Option A is correct because infants under 6 months old have a high risk of severe pertussis and should be treated with prophylaxis. Option B is incorrect because prophylactic treatment is only recommended for close contacts with infants under 6 months old or those at high risk for complications. Option C is incorrect because natural immunity to pertussis wanes over time and she may need a booster vaccine in the future. Option D is incorrect because only those who are not up-to-date on their TdaP vaccination should receive a booster.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Option A is correct because infants are at higher risk for severe complications from pertussis, and prophylactic treatment with azithromycin is recommended for household contacts. Option B is incorrect because prophylactic treatment is not recommended for classmates. Option C is incorrect because natural immunity against pertussis does wane over time. Option D is incorrect because only those who have not received the recommended TdaP booster should receive it, not all classmates regardless of vaccination status.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Option A is correct because infants less than 1 year old are at highest risk of severe complications from pertussis and should be treated with antibiotics as prophylaxis. Option B is incorrect because there is no need for prophylaxis for the classmates of a patient with pertussis unless they are in close contact with an infant less than 1 year old. Option C is incorrect because although the patient will have immunity against Bordetella pertussis, it is not lifelong and wanes over time. Option D is incorrect because while TdaP booster is recommended for all adults, it is not specifically indicated for classmates of a patient with pertussis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Option A is correct because the 3-month-old brother is at high risk for contracting pertussis and should be treated prophylactically with macrolide antibiotics. Option B is incorrect as classmates should only be treated prophylactically if they have prolonged close contact with the patient. Option C is incorrect as lifelong immunity is not guaranteed, and individuals can get re-infected. Option D is incorrect because only those who are not up-to-date on their pertussis vaccine should receive a TdaP booster.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Azithromycin prophylaxis is recommended for household contacts of patients with confirmed or suspected pertussis, especially those under 1 year of age. Clarithromycin is not recommended for prophylaxis. The patient may have some immunity but it is not lifelong or complete, and TdaP booster is only recommended for those who have not received it before or if it has been 10 years since their last booster.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. For option (A), the CDC recommends providing antibiotic prophylaxis to close contacts of pertussis patients who are at high risk for severe disease or complications, including infants less than 1 year of age who are household or close contacts of a pertussis patient, as pertussis is most severe in infants. Option (B) is not recommended by the CDC, as it is only recommended to treat symptomatic contacts rather than providing prophylaxis. Option (C) is false, as natural immunity to pertussis is not lifelong and wanes over time. Option (D) is not necessary for all classmates, but it is recommended for those who have not received a TdaP vaccination in the past 10 years.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. For option A, it is recommended to treat household contacts of an individual with confirmed pertussis, especially those who are younger than 12 months old, with azithromycin as prophylaxis. Option B is incorrect, as only close contacts (household contacts or those who have face-to-face contact) of the patient with pertussis should receive prophylaxis. Option C is incorrect, as natural immunity against pertussis wanes over time, and individuals can contract pertussis multiple times. Option D is incorrect, as TdaP booster is recommended for individuals 11-18 years of age who have completed the childhood DTaP series and for adults aged 19-64 years who have not previously received a TdaP booster, but it is not necessary for all classmates of the patient with pertussis regardless of their vaccination status.
